content: A friend suggested something to me today and I wanted to run it past some Vets. He told me of a tentative plan to bring the Aircraft Carrier "Ranger" to Portland and turn it into a bunch of shops and restaurants. Myself having visited the Aircraft Carrier "Midway" and having seen the Aircraft Carrier "Reagan" from a distance am impressed with the whole idea of bringing these ships into town and using them for museums. I however have some reservations about using them as anything other than museums. But to get to the point a RESPECTED Navy Veteran from Milwaukee Oregon suggested putting it in Astoria on Tongue Point and turning into a Casino and using the profits from the casino to help veterans. What do you think? Would it diminish the importance and symbolism of a great ship as the "Ranger" to be relegated to blue haired ladies and Haute' Cuisine? Would it be an insult to a great ship or an asset to Veterans programs? Quantum materiae materietur marmota monax si marmota monax materiam possit materiari?

I however have some reservations about using them as anything other than museums. But to get to the point a RESPECTED Navy Veteran from Milwaukee Oregon suggested putting it in Astoria on Tongue Point and turning into a Casino and using the profits from the casino to help veterans. What do you think? Would it diminish the importance and symbolism of a great ship as the "Ranger" to be relegated to blue haired ladies and Haute' Cuisine? Would it be an insult to a great ship or an asset to Veterans programs? Quantum materiae materietur marmota monax si marmota monax materiam possit materiari?
title: Casino "Ranger"

content: I think it might be good for Veterans ORG., if no local BS was attached. I would pay to go aboard a museum and take tours, buy nic nacs and such. I don’t think Sailors would mind showing off Navel history, work stations, the workings of a Carrier and educating the public. GWG is right about the merchants…would they stand by while the crowds went else where? I would rather see a piece of history then a artificial reef made out of this Carrier. Break glass…in case of Emergency! Or, just wait till I get to the bottom of the bottle!

title: Casino "Ranger"

content: Hmmmm....tough question. Museum - sure a VFW/American Legion type of crowd, dance club in a hanger - sure working restuarant - why not Casino - I don't know. Thinking about my own two years serving on a USCG Cutter is all I have to relate to. I don't know that I would like that idea. Not suggesting a casino would ever fit onto a ship like I was on, rather, I'm just wondering how past crews of the Ranger would feel about it. Maybe they will show up here and comment. Don
reply: Hmmmm....tough question. Museum - sure a VFW/American Legion type of crowd, dance club in a hanger - sure working restuarant - why not Casino - I don't know. Thinking about my own two years serving on a USCG Cutter is all I have to relate to. I don't know that I would like that idea. Not suggesting a casino would ever fit onto a ship like I was on, rather, I'm just wondering how past crews of the Ranger would feel about it. Maybe they will show up here and comment. Don
title: Casino "Ranger"

content: NO to a Casino. Veterans might get 10% of the profits but the employees, owners, State, and Federal Gov't would get the other 90%. Like the North Carolina Lottery, the profits were to go for education in our schools but it seems that all we are producing are kids that graduate with a degree in drugs.

title: Casino "Ranger"

content: As far as gambling on a former Navy Ship- When I was on the U.S.S. Blue Ridge (LCC-19), there was a lot of games offered, underway. Depending where you were on the ship, pretty much spoke to the stakes required to buy-in. Legal or not, by Naval Regs, didn't seem to matter much as there were ALL ranks involved (enlisted and officer). As to respect for the former sailors who served aboard her? Well, I'm quite sure IF a casino were in the offering, there would NOT be gaming in the Chaplin's office, and other places of long-standing tradition/serious use. Those places would be best used as display/history destinations for tours. Personally, if one of my former vessels were to be turned into a casino, I would gladly visit her, and even drop a dime here and there..... More, if it were designated a non-profit for Vets!!
reply: As far as gambling on a former Navy Ship- When I was on the U.S.S. Blue Ridge (LCC-19), there was a lot of games offered, underway. Depending where you were on the ship, pretty much spoke to the stakes required to buy-in. Legal or not, by Naval Regs, didn't seem to matter much as there were ALL ranks involved (enlisted and officer). As to respect for the former sailors who served aboard her? Well, I'm quite sure IF a casino were in the offering, there would NOT be gaming in the Chaplin's office, and other places of long-standing tradition/serious use. Those places would be best used as display/history destinations for tours.
